title-group.article-title: Preface: Special topical issue on nonlinear energy harvesting

article-meta.issue-title: Special Topical Issue on Nonlinear Energy Harvesting

caption.p: Assistant Professor, G. W. Woodruff School of Mechanical Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332. E-mail: alper.ertuk@me.gatech.edu

body.p: Conventional energy harvesters that are based on the linear resonance phenomenon, such as tuned cantilevers, often suffer from frequency bandwidth limitations and their extreme sensitivity to uncertainties. If system parameters, such as the excitation frequency, manufacturing tolerances, or ambient temperature, are altered slightly, the linear resonance condition may fail to be achieved, resulting in drastically reduced power output in a lightly damped harvester. These limitations of the so-called linear energy harvesters as well as the essential nonlinearities occasionally observed in these devices gave rise to research on nonlinear energy harvesting in the last few years. The primary goal is frequency bandwidth and performance enhancement by introducing nonlinearities through magnetoelastic buckling (Cottone et al., 2009; Erturk et al., 2009) or purely elastic buckling (Arrieta et al., 2010; Masana and Daqaq, 2011), stoppers (Soliman et al., 2008) and free play (Sousa et al., 2011), among others, while the essential nonlinearities typically result from geometric, material and dissipative (Stanton et al., 2012) effects under high excitation levels.

This special issue of the Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures brings together a collection of some of the most recent work on nonlinear energy harvesting with a coverage of different energy conversion mechanisms, such as piezoelectric and electrostatic transduction techniques, as well as multiphysics problems, such as self-excited nonlinear limit-cycle oscillations in flow energy harvesting.

I would like to thank the authors for their technical contributions. I would also like to thank Prof. Norman M. Wereley for editing this special issue. I sincerely hope you enjoy reading this collection.
